title: 104_hr4162
content: The Act titled "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to allow certain individuals to continue participating in defined benefit plans. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, ensuring no break in service with the employer for the purpose of benefit accrual. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Terms of continued participation exclude earnings and forfeitures, with any liability allocated by the plan sponsor or the last employer. The period of participation extends until the participant reaches normal retirement age or the end of the plan. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The plan requires timely payment of contributions, and qualified beneficiaries are liable for funding any obligations to provide benefits. Contributions are allocated to qualified beneficiaries in the same manner as employer and employee contributions. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Contributions are allocated to beneficiaries based on their voluntary contributions, limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period, and can be made in monthly installments. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Contributions can be made in monthly installments, with a 45-day grace period before the first payment is due. The election period is at least 90 days, and any election made by one qualified beneficiary includes other beneficiaries as well. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. A qualified beneficiary is any beneficiary under the plan on the day before the qualifying event, including the participant in certain cases. A qualifying event is defined as specific events occurring within seven years of the participant reaching normal retirement age, which would otherwise result in the cessation of benefit accruals. Qualified beneficiaries can continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, such as the termination or reduction of hours of employment, or the death of the participant. The Act applies to plan years starting on or after July 1, 1996, with a special rule for defined benefit plans under collective bargaining agreements, not applying before the termination of agreements or January 1, 2000.
